description.narrative: IFC and Standard Chartered Bank (SCB), UK are jointly considering to establish a trade finance facility of up to US$300 million to help reduce periodic acute fuel shortages in Ghana. The facility will provide private sector bulk distribution companies (BDCs) in Ghana access to oil import financing facilities, enabling the BDCs to import petroleum product cargoes on a regular basis, thereby helping reduce fuels shortages in Ghana. Of the total facility amount, IFCs exposure will be up to US$150 mn through a risk sharing arrangement, whereby, IFC will effectively share the underlying credit risk of the BDCs with SCB.

The project is designed to have a development impact in terms of:
Reducing Supply Interruptions: Improving access to trade finance is designed to help the BDCs import product on a regular basis, alleviating the occurrence of petroleum product shortages in Ghana;
Private Sector Development: The facility is designed have a role in supporting independent private sector players.; and
Supplementing Existing Facilities: The project supplements the facilities offered by local banks and IFC's GTFP program by providing additional cost effective trade financing solutions in the Ghanaian market and helping increase the overall trade finance flows to the country.
IFC proposes to monitor the following key development impacts during the life of IFCâ?s investment:
- The volume of petroleum products imported in Ghana through the use of this facility - The number of BDCs using this facility - The total storage infrastructure established by the BDCs in Ghana in terms of capacity

name.narrative: Standard Chartered Bank is headquartered in London, United Kingdom and operates in over 70 countries. The project involves providing structured trade finance to Ghanas BDCs, which import and supply petroleum products in bulk to the countrys retailers. Most of these BDCs are headquartered in Accra, Ghana.
